economic_impact: New testimony from pharmacy employers indicates a willingness to pay the registration costs for their technicians. This suggests the direct financial burden of the new fees may be borne by businesses rather than individual employees. Industry stakeholders view the measure as a reasonable and necessary investment to ensure workforce competency and patient safety.
policy_impact: This measure is now framed as a direct and necessary follow-up to Act 104, Session Laws of Hawaii 2024, which expanded the scope of practice for pharmacy technicians to include administering immunizations. Testimony emphasizes that requiring registration provides an essential regulatory framework and public safety oversight for these expanded responsibilities. The bill solidifies the professionalization of pharmacy technicians in alignment with their evolving roles.
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The primary updates clarify the economic and policy context based on new testimony. Economically, it is now noted that employers have expressed willingness to cover the registration costs for their technicians. From a policy perspective, the bill is now explicitly linked as a necessary regulatory follow-up to the expanded scope of practice authorized by Act 104 SLH 2024.
